monogr.title: The triall of Christian truht [sic] by the rules of the vertues, namelie these principall, faith, hope, charitie and religion, seruing for the discouerie of heresie, and antichrist, in his forerunners and misteries of iniquitie. The second parte, entreating of hope : wherein is made manifest, that the pretended hope of the Protestant, empeaching the merits of Christ, his holy grace, and man his vertuouse life, destroyeth all true confidence in allmightie God, either exceding in presumption, or wanting in desperation / by Edward Weston

div.head: THE EPISTLE TO THE COVRTEOVSE READER.
div.p: THERE is nothing so sacred, which is not in some sorte infested by impietie, or so pure and vndefiled, that man his malice endeuoreth not vpon occasion to pollute & corrupte. But for that suche practises are in their oune proper shapes and natures passing vglie and detestable, therupon wilie witt in them playeth conning pranckes, and laboreth earnestlie to make that seeme holie, which is plotted against all sanctitie, that to appeare shining bright, which is ordained to oppresse and extinguish the verie beames of the sunne with an infernall vampe of error and foule transgression. Which manner of craftie maliciouse intendemēt is in no one kinde, as more ruefull to feele, so nether more veuable to beholde, then in the progresse of heresie & heretickes againest faith and children of the Ghospell: whose endeuors either are so couert lie couched in the treanche of deepe dissimulation, or so gorgiouslie sett oute vpon the stage in the fained coulors of hipocrisie, that none shall be able to discrie the treacherouse conceilement of the one, and the false varnished splendour of the other, vnlesse his watchefull Prudence be balased beloe with humilitie, and his humble obedience be reared vp oboue to the height and light of discreete vigilancie.

When Abrahams seruantes had by digging founde oute sundrie fountainesG • n. 26. for the commoditie of cleare water in the soile of Palestina, the inhabitans of the Countrie enuying his successe as it seemed, with violence dammed them vp by quantitie of earth cast into their discouered Springes: the which notwithstanding after by the industrie of his sonne Isaac were cleansed, and in them the liquor was brought againe to wholesome vse, and natiue perfection. Wherupon did then arise a new manner of opposition betwixt the homebred shepheardes of Gerara, and those of his owne retineue: whenas his prophane enimies did not now as before in Abrahams dayse, by strength of arme glutt and stopp them vp, but maintained claime vnder a false title vnto them: & so by sclaunder and emnitie sought to impatronise themselues with proprietie of such preciouse
treasures, which before God his people helde in lawfull possessiō.Orig▪ Homil 13. in c. 26. Ge. In like sorte what aunci • nt fou • taines of deuine doctrine we haue bequeathed vs from the labors of the P • t •• arckes, and Prophets; or of later inuention discouered vnto vs by our Sauiour Christ, and his Apostles, some bende their force • with the Iewe and Gentill by earthlie and carnall interpretations, or els by might of perseq • ution, vtt •• lie to abolish, and so to drie vp the water of them euen to the darkenes of obliuion. Others not professing their totall extermination, to wit h • ret • kes, cōmence suict. againest their trewe owners by clamorouse comba • ments, ir • full inst • um • ntes of furie, to entitle themselues Lordes ou • r • uch endowments, to which equitie affordeth not them an • e allowable interest, or i • stifi •• le pr • tenc • . Notwithstanding in ishue of effecte, heretickes as th • y st ••• e ag • inest vs Catholickes to be commaunders of the fountaines, so not contente with the lordeshipp of them, moreouer seeke by their vs •• p • tion to defile them: with the Pagan and Iewe accorde in this fi • all pro • ect • , that they, as monumentes and headspringes of faith, be 〈◊〉 vp with clods and rubbish of infidelitie and idolatrie.

It h •• he beene auerred in the precedent Treatise, that our assured assentAu • ust in 〈◊〉
of • ill and vnderstanding s •• rendred to saith, as vpon rocke and ancher doeth depende vpon some outeward auctoritie, through poyes of remar • keable grauitie pr • u • l •• t with such, who prudentlie are to iudge what is to be b • leued, & what to be • schewed fals • ly recommended vntoRom. •• . them as matter of that heauenlie qualitie. In regard wherof the Apostle S. Paule pronounced, faith to be engendered by hearing, and hearing employed aboute the same, to be directed to the worde of God. Wherefore that faith may be attained by hearing, not on • lie is to be attended a soun • ing Voice of the Preacher, but all so the propertie of him as catechist is to be considered: in that from him onelie are wee dutifullie to heare in this important affaire, who according to a iudiciouse calculatiō is founde to be a deuine messenger of the holie Ghoste: for otherwise emong manie Doctors and maisters in contrariety, our attentiue hearing should be vncertaine, distractiue, and so liable to the decciptes of forging dissemblers and false Relligionars. Wherefore when we haue by a prudent examine once founde oute the waight and moment of aucthoritie, then in vertue of the same may wee maturelie esteeme the Preachers wordes as the verie wordes of allmightie God, deliuered vnto vs from the mouthe of man, as from his oracle of approued seruice and designed ministerie. For by the worde of God the Apostle in that place did not meane the whritten worde, but rather the worde of the churche in her preaching tradition: in that the worde of the Ghospell was not then registred
by letters when he vttered that doctrine: and allso for that, manyI • en lib. 1. c. 5. barbarouse Nations conuerted to the faith of Christ, not knouing any recorde of scripture, neuerthelesse in their first conuersions, and originall matriculations in the societie of God his people, as they conceiued faith b • hearing, so allso d • ubtlesse did they • hen heare the worde of God beleuing. Therefore the most assured, breife and substantiall method how to stick to tr • uth when the ear • , instrument of faith and discipline, is assailed by fals •• ie, is exactlie to discusse, which contradictorie partie is auouched by gre • ter and better aucthoritie, as through more ample number of beleuers, elder professiō, orderlie mission, more eminent sanctitie, more famouse explo • tes in the processe of veritie and vertue: then herupon respectiuely it will be approuable by reason, relying on the one, to censure as lighte, weake, not worthie our admirtance suche pretended auctoritie, which in balāce of triall shall appear • deuoide of all those prerogatiues of deuine grauitie and maiestie. According to which manner of proceding S. Augustin by waye of ponderou • e aucthoritie doeth not onely excellently well prescribe in generall against all heresie banded in armes to infest the Catholick faith, but moreouer still disputing in particular against the Manichies, the Donatistes, the Pelagians, applieth this capitall Prescription from outward aucthoritie to the present controuerlie: and therby not onelie Theologicallie, but allso prudently, as eache intelligent persone may in like Case, concludeth for the Catholick faith againest their heresies. And vpon this grounde, comperatiuely valeuing the presumptuouse aucthoritie of Protestants with that of Catholickes, it hath beene by me demonstrated, that naturall prudence doth geue sentence for vs againest them: and most euidently haue we made it good, that Protestantes for w • nte of this outeward competent aucthoritie, consequently haue no meanes to setle and ancher themselues in substance, in constancie, in vnitie of beleefe, to conuerte Pagans, to reclaime heretickes, or to condemne their errors as iustely reproueable.

Bu • what semeth in this poincte to me most considerable, is this: thatCir. in exposit Symb. Nicen. wereas the Protestante clearelie perceiueth, that outewarde aucthoritie of grace and worthe stanneth not for him, but rather for vs, and in fronte of hostilitie against his faction, therupon turneth he his batterie to demolish and beate doune this grande outeward aucthoritie diuersely empeaching the same: & so in effecte manifesteth himselfe an auoued souldier of Antichrist. For yf once his impiouse and rebelliouse pride should preuaile against auctoritie in the affaire of faith: yf he shall dismantle faith of the safegard & state of aucthoritie, forthwith must faith perish, as a tree despoiled of the barcke, as a plante depriued of heauens influence,
as the conducte wanting the pipe: then must there be no pregnant argumentes lefte to r • concile the infidell or misbeleuer, no supporte remnante to a certaine wauering Christians, no preseruatiue extant againest the infection of heresies and seduction: and then herupon must all Christian pietie and beleefe, as the Protestant formindeth, breath oute their vitall spiritt into atheisme & paganrie. In this respect deseruedly Aetius, as whriteth Socrates, was suruamed the Atheist, for that disdainefully he misprised the aucthoritie of commentaries endighted by the learned Fathers, relying whollie in resolution vpon his owne priuate expositionsSocrat l 2. Hist. c. 28. deuising this or that pretenddely, as sense deducted frō the sacred Texte. Allso for this selfe same consideration S. Athanasius calleth Arius anAthanasius. orat 2. cont. A • ian. Atheist, all thoughe in counterfeict resemblance he vrged scriptures to fortifie his heresie, in the meane season contemning aucthoritie, and boasting of himselfe as peculiarly illuminated by allmightie God. And as concerning the Protestant, yf we once thincke with him, that the churche, from which in perplexitie we are to receiue assurance, in strife to gaigne repose, to be inuisible, shrouded and buried in the bouells of darcknes, what purpose is it for vs in searche to make repaire to her mansion place or tribunall of iudgement? Yf we conceipte, as Protestants doe, that the teaching aucthoritie of the churche may erre, and hath often times made lapse into falsitie, whie shoulde we now for the present creditt her definitions, peremptorely auouching, these whriringes to be the very worde of God Ghostly from him inspired: allmightie God to be one in substance, and triple in personalitie: the second persone in the B. Trinitie to be incarnated for the worldes redemptiō, seing that in these, as well as in others matters by her indifferently recommended vnto vs, she may decline from veritie, and all conformite with the prime & eternall truthe? Whereupon abandoning churchlie aucthoritie, we must remaine lefte to our owne tiring deuises, and so flitt and wander, as shall please poore reason frō her weake vigour changeably to geue vs information. Then at the the first brandeling steppe into a labarinth, shall we entertaine opiniō with the Arians, that it smallie importeth our saluation of what secte be our faith in sundrie particular poinctes, so after owne deuised fashion we beleue in God & Christe: who as recordeth Athanasius, thought to be an Athana. orat. 2 con Arian. Epist ad. stud v •• . sol •• . indifferent thing the asse • tiō of Arins, & thereupō equallie stiled them good Christians, who followed the same. In like manner shall we consorte with Donatistes, who as witnesseth S. Augustin accounted it a matter meerely disputable the practice of rebaptising. Allso shall we ioyne • shue with PelagiansAug •• ▪ cont. Cr •• con. c. 4. D •
• ecc • to o •• g c 2 • . denying the necessitie of grace to good life: In whiche thing, sayed they, as aduertiseth vs the same S. Augustin, yf we be conninced to haue erred, yet our errour will
not appeare otherwise a faulte, then against ciuilitie. After beeing possessed with this caruing conceipte in matter and obiecte of deuine faith, crying oute with the strumpet Diuidatur, lert variances in beelefe haue free pasportes3. Reg. • . to trauaile withoute losse throughe damnation, our priuate deuises in mutiny phantasying this or that, not geuing vs full cōtentment, doubting of all shall we rushe vpon atheisme, and losing sense and spiritt of heauen, finally die in the hidiouse gulfe therof. And h • re • s staked the dismall and blacke period of Protestancie auiling and neglecting the regardeableAug. epi. •••
aucthoritie of the Catholick churche. Que est enim peior mors animae, quàm libertas erroris? what death • f the soule worse, then fredome to erre? For as hathe bene declared againest the Protestante, his misprisall of outewarde aucthoritie concerning i •• efragable iudicature in questions controuersed, importing assured deliuerie of the cathechisme to all desirouse of instruction, openeth the gappe to distrus • e, to dissentions, to all heresies, and at lenght to rennegacie of faith and infidelitie purposed by Antichrist, and his vnuersall bande of enroled complices. Then Christian Reader, I doubte not, but that thou haste vnderstoode by the precedenr parte, firste, that by vertue of naturall prudence, yf for thy direction in the affaire of faith thou resoluest to folloue any teaching auctoritie, thow atte absolutely to followe that, which stanneth for the Catholik Romane beleefe: that of the protestant, in veue and verdicte therof, not beeing equall, or in any sorte comparable. Secondly haste thow learned, how that the Protestā • by diuerse his positions, purposely applied to disgrace all outewarde aucthoritie of the churche, as denouncing, or rather renouncing it as inuisible, as pl • able to error, as subiect to the examine & censure of euerie priuate spirit, as for many hundreds of yeares in seruice of Antichrist to haue displaied his banner of crueltie, of falsitie, of impietie: in defiance of Christe and Christian veritie to haue enacted sundrie Canons and decrees, laboreth hereby to destroy the ordinarie instrument of the Holie Ghoste for the persuading of faith, and nurrishing the same; & so maketh entrance for rude, blouddie, cruell, sauage atheisme, with barbarouse neglecte of all diuinitie.

Moreouer for that the totall office of a Christian is not abridged in theLactant lib. 1. I • st • ▪ Chri • o. Homil. quod Nemo laeditur. sole worke of faith, but allso is enlarged to a vertuouse life: and in this respected most eminently, for that our sauiour Christ, guider therunto, in regarde of the deitie of his persone, puritie of his doctrine, and price of his deserte, is most highe, souerane, and efficaciouse, therfore suruay is now to be made, to what p • tche of excellencie in this kinde is leuelled this Catholik beleefe; then vpon what border burteth the d • siguised credulitie of the protestant. In discussion of which matters are to be employed
the ensuing controuersies apertaining to Hope, Charitie, & Relligion.

Athanasius playe the parte of the subtle serpent, inuesting it selfe in the sac •• d s • ow • o • holy Scriptures, therby in secrecie to make entrie into the paradice of Christ his Catholick churche, and in that place in agencie for Antichrist to ••• ade Christ, intending to diminish his excellencie, ether in his person, in his meritt, or in his graciouse beneuolence imparted to man kinde. And for that this highe degre of imparted goodnes is espetially aimed at by our sauiour Christ, as • ruicte and ende of all, to witt that his faithfull children be in worcke and action of life excellently innocent, ritchely abundant, and so, as in a prime sorte conformable to right reason, so allso moste agreable to allmightie God, aucthor and giuer of the same: herupō Heretickes vnder a pretended title of holy writt, and of magnifying Christ, haue s • ily endeuoured to empare in man this perfection of vertue throughe Christ, yea contrariewise, to entice him to impure and dissolute liberty by a priuilege of a fained Ghospell: at laste to force him to the thralldome of Antichristiā seruility through sinne and wickednes. Wherefore the Fathers wrighting againest Pagans, emong
〈◊〉 li. • cent. Iul • an. Aug Epist. 3. 5. other argumentes to proue vnto them our Christian beleefe to bee prudently credible, & to be entertained iudiciously by all, haue vrged this as most pregnant and forcible, that our holy faith aboue whatsomeuer other institutions of humane Philosophy, or coulorable inuentions of painted Poetrie, is most persuasiue and vigorouse for vertue: namely to to combine man with God in pietie, man with man in charitie, and in all integritie of conuersation. Marcke I pray the, writeth S. Augustin to hisAug. • p • . 202. l. • . quest. v •• . & N •• . Test. c. 7. Freinde Nectarius, with what prayses in the Catholick Churche are recommended frugalitie, continencie, and in regarde of wedlock fidelitie, and to conclude, all other honest and good manners. In which when anie Cittie dothe excell, it may be truly sayed, that it florisheth. And when as some made argument against the Catholick faith, as preiudiciall to the estates of Princes, and common wealthes, the same Doctor thus discouereth their humor, and preposterouse intended pollicie: Therfore they thinck, or seeme so to doe, that the Christiā doctrine is contrarie to the common vtilitie, because they will not, that the common Augu. Epist. 3. waalth doe stande by the power of vertue, but rather by the impuritie of vice. Le • t then suche as auouche the Christian doctrine to be repugnant to the commonwealth, geue me such an armie of men, accordinglie as the Christian doctrine enformeth souldiers, let them geue me such gouerners, suche husbandes, suche wiues, suche parentes, suche children, suche Lordes, suche seruantes, such kinges, suche Iudges: to conclude suche payers of debtes, and exacters of princes rentes, as are appoincted by the Christian
doctrine, and then lett them dare affirme the same to be hurtefull to commonwealthes, or doubte to confesse, the same, • f it b • followed, to be most commod • o • se vnto commonwealthes.

And allthough vertue, in regard that it is a qualitie agreable vnto a reasonable soule, is in a degree most eminently pleasant therunto, and as it were the liquor of hunnie flowing aboute the sense of tast, yet notwithstanding for that the intellectuall inuention of that medioc • it • e, which is the marke aimed at by mans will, in the obiecte therof, is not all Waise easiely discried by euerie minde, and much more harde is it, to holde on that action bente by resolution towardes the same, when sensuall perturbations are a floote, and stande furiously in a • mes for the opposite vice, therfore it semeth, that it is accompanied with contrarieties, as being light and darcke to the intelligence, deliciouse and harshe, facill and troublesome vnto the affection. Euerie man as speaketh the PrinceA •• st 〈◊〉 . • a Moral. ca. ••
of the Philosophers, can drawe forthe a circle, but to po • ncte oute the center therof, is a thinge very difficulte. Wherfore allthough it be an easie matter to discerne in iudgement what is the mediocritie of euerie perturbation, yet to keepe in action this mediocritie, wherby we are made praysworthy, i • a busin • sse passing d •• fi •• ll. And therfore it is a reare thing to be an honest man. It falleth ou • e often times, that the amiable hewe of vertue is shadowed with suche outeward representations, as doe not onlie hide the trew luster therof •• om the vulgar eye, but allso vnto the same make it contemptible and dispriseable. What sp •
ctacle Aug▪ ••• . 3 • n •• . •• . more loathsome, sayeth S. Augustin, then martirdome, • f a man aske the question of his carnall eyse? yet what thing more • aire, yf he enquire of the eyse of the haerte? Whoe can easelie perceiue the splendor of patience shining in holy Iob sitting vpon the dunghill, the carbuncle of zeale in Daniell buried in the lions denne, in S. Peter, and S. Paule emprisoned, tyed in chaines, banished, in wante and indigence, dying violent deathes▪ or whoe can with Abraham in expedition of a decreed purpose holde vp an arme made cruell with a sworde, to kill his best & onely deare Isaac emong all his wo • dlie delightes and contentements! wherfore in that Philosophie and Heathenish Poeterie were insufficient to geue vs this directionCi •• l lib. 10. T • esaur. ca 3. of minde to finde oute vertue, to entertai • e this courage of wi • l to pursue the same, the sonne of God became man, intelligible by his doctrine, and imitable by his ensample, to the ende we might know vertue, and consequentlie be enamoured with the beautie therof. The Pagans as writethIoseph. in Pr •• at. A •• iqui • . Iosephus, imputed to their Gods shamefull factes, and hereupon encreased the malice of euill disposed persons for the accomplishment of all wickednes. And as vpō reuew of histories wee may easely proue, that the ciuil • st and sue • est sorte of people, liuing euer vpon the earth, to haue be • e Christians, so may
we know, that oure profession beefore all other hath ariued therunto, in reconing that it hath beene addicted to vertue in all excellencie, which intelligenceth the minde, and ridding the will of all harshenes, sweteneth it in amitie, pietie, charitie; and so draweth the whole man from the leese of sensualitie, That, as speaketh S. Augustin, As the beautie of the bodie Augu T •• . 32. i • 7. c. Iohan. 2. P • t. 1. is the soule, so the beautie of the s • ule be allmightie God. Happie and desired lucifer, expected by the sacred Apostle S. Peter, to arise in the haertes of all trew beleeuers! No glittering masse of goulde or siluer, no riche Iuellrie of pearl • s and precio • se stones yea as speaketh Aristotle, no princelie empire, by which mortall men doe much r • semble allmightie God, bringethArist. l. 1. Mag Mor. c. 4. & 6. man to that top a • d tipe of dignitie, to that degre of honor and ciuill respecte, to which vertue causeth him to mounte and aspire. Vpon which consideration, Courteouse Reade, in regard of Ciuilitie, thou a •• e diligentli • to marke and ponder, which faith stanneth more effectuallie for documentes to enforme the vnderstanding, for restraincte, and incicitements allso of the will, to inure the same in all vertuouse actions: for hereupon dependeth thy coll • ctiue conclusion, to censure which faith and relligion are truly ciuill and politicke, and which balefull thereunto. And withoute all doubte, the ende and drifte of nature drauing men to vnitie and combination of Cittie, and common wealth, was not only by reciprocall commerce to enriche the inhabitants, to make them abounde in pleasure, but espetially that they should be hereby vertuouse, & that in a better manner, then they coulde be liuing sauadgely in distraction and vagrancie: for otherwise vertue set a side, greater calamitie, and sharp •• miserie, will accompanie Citizens, Rulers, and subiectes, then yf they liued in sequestration vpon mountaines, in wodes or dennes: for that the malice and luste of man are then moste potent, when they be armed with dissimulation, with crafte, where the partie assailing may contriue what he liste: which trickes of vnnaturall pollicie haue commonly for schoole the cour • e where vertue is wanting, for feelde and theater the common wealthe, for vpsho • barbaritie, and hatefull disunion. Farthermore yf in this affaire, not relying on reasons discourse, we will solely beholde the pole st • r of heauen the prouidence of allmightie God, we shall euen by experience know, that only vertue is ciuill and politick; in that vertue only is mother of loue, of honor of prosperitie, with oute which no tricking descant, or odiouse coosenage of a barbarouse politician, can make any common wealth truly ciuill, or for wisdome commendable. What braue and greate exploites, I pray you, are brought to passe by this new glosse, by this forged coyne, by his • ascar • e altering nature in false viso • s, by these clokes, which strike no thing but that
which is not? where are at home their aboundance, their contented and vnited mindes, their trustefull repo •• s in each others ••• iance? where are abrode their trophies of armes, and letters, of redoubted puisance & renoume, of faithfull leauge and amitie? where is their same, which maugre death, and the whole heape of its funeralls, glo •• fi • th the name against lenghte of time, or enuie of the wicked? what is then the summe? A litel time to be dissolute, by litel and litel in time to dissolue all: and after time to be eternally and miserably tormented. Heare the iudgement of Iosephus, a sage Historiographer emong tha leues. We may vnderstand, Ioseph. Prae
• at An • iq. tha • such commun • ties as are obedient to the will of allmightie God, and are afraied to violate lawes well decreed, to be prosperouse in all suc • esse aboue humane c • nc • ipte: to whom allmightie God for reward proposeth • elicitie. But contrariewise yf the departe from the obseruance of th • m, their deuis • s finally come to no good ende: moreouer their endeuors, which vnto them seeme good, expire in most remedilesse calamities.

Wherupon in dewe consequence doeth it follow, that as the ChristianPla • o li • ▪ de Repub A • ist. •

No famouse Philosopher endoued o • ely with the light of reason, as commendable to posteritie, hathe hetherto written of ciuill institution, who hath no • laied dou • n as grounde of such discipline vertue, and that good abearance betwixt man and man, which is conform • ble to right reason, and by meanes therof auaileable to the communitie: allso supposing fell barbaritie, opposite to ciuilitie, to be no thing els but a frouard distraction of man from man through vice and wickednes, • ther ou • ewarely breaking into furie, or closely conceiled vnder the resemblance of probiti • , infestingst artifically all honest decencie of life and comportement: for as well (to geue an example) stanneth in oppositiō against iustice the ingenering Burglar, attempting his enterprice in the dearckenes of the night,Dissimilite • nocent sed non dissimilit • r •• piunt Aug P • aef. in Psal. 9 • . as the open theefe attending his booty on the highe way side. Most apparant is it then, the new founde kinde • of pollicie, attributed by some to theese our dayese, as to a sager age, vaunted and vented forth frō the pen of Nicholas Ma •••• uill, to be naught els but an artificall introduction of barbarisme, the nourcery in deede of all vice, the torment of of mens soules and bodies, the impeachement of the communitie, bicause it beareth strong heade against vertue, the pillar and ho •• combe of ciuill life & conuersation. Yf the Rulers securitie must be founded vpon the deboshementes of the bodies and soules of his subiectes, as vpō their luxurie, their incontinencie, their roietousnes, their prodigalitie: Yf his
assured staye must arise from their disagremente, their • uspitions, treacherise, riualitise, hostilitise, in recknoning of diuersitie in relligions or otherwise emong them: yf his wealth is to be purchased from their penuries, their bondage, frō their base couardely & ignorant dispositions: as that Florentine Scribe aduer •• seth Princes, iust according to the • enor of Barbarisme, excellentlie described and politickly reiected by Aristotle,Ari l 5. Po • it. cap 1 • . then suppose wee, that freinde and freinde, mayster and seruant, lauwer and client, P •• sition and patient, souldior and • ustick, marchant and gentleman, husband and wise, be thus likewise aff • cted correspondently to the Idaea of a Prince towardes his subiectes, and theese towards him, (as one will certainly ensue of the other) and then tell me in this mutiny of vice, in this • nisprision of vertue, in this anxietie of feare and dreade, in this egar pu •• uicte ofter priuate luste o • lukar, what ci •• litie will remayne in a common wealth, what bonde in • olablye combining citizens▪ or rather 〈◊〉 be confessed, that sauagenes will make her trophey, as vpō the spo • les of vertue, so vpon the ou • rthroe of • rew sounde and solid 〈◊〉 . In which respecte, cour • eouse Reader, thou shalt vnderstāde, of what importe is it, to entertaine & embrace the Catholick Romane faith, euen ciuill state of humane societie meerly considered, it recommeding vnto the so eff • ctually vertue, the sole instrument of good pollicie, and repressing so pouerably iniquity, the proper engine of cruell and disorderly 〈◊〉 .

Withoute all doubte yf we shall in seuerall by ioincte and member anato •• se he belefe of Protestants, we shall beholde it according to the whole 〈◊〉 therof, to haue progenie, as mightely biased with carnalitie and 〈◊〉 , from these three Heades: to witt for the vnderstanding, that it be freed from commaunding aucthoritie of menn: that the will be licenced in liberty from conscionable subiection to Princes: and that sensuall concupiscence beare sway as not controble by remorse of conscience, or opinion of spirituall hurte from any sinfull transgression: all which are so many elementes and letters, which spell barbaritie. Of the former hath beene made a su •• icient remonstrance in the precedent parte: the other to we are easely strained frō the pregnancie of their doctrine. In generall it is the humor of an Heretick, to be barbarouse in furiouse and • bidinouse outerage, resembled by those horses in the Apocalips, whose hurtfull mighte was In their mo • thes, and in their tailes: wherupō very elegantly thus S. Gregorie: Theese horses, that is naughty Preachers, Apoc 9. Greg l 33 in • ob. cap 29. running euerie where by the instincte of carnalitie, haue power in ther mouthes, and in their tailes: for that preaching peruerse thinges, and beeing borne oute by the temporall magistrate, they exalte them selues by ba • kward and wordly meanes. Were
not Luther and Calmn in this respecte barbed horses of Antichrist, to induce barbarisme, whose rebelliouse mouthes breathed out a relligion contrarie to the whol churche then beeing regnante? whas not their tailes allso pouerable, when promising men securitie in all lustefull liberty, drew many to the carion of their dunghill? wicklefth, that disgraciouse monster of ōur nation, did he not poyson the aire, bane the bodies and soules of millions with incitementes to turpitude of life, auouching that God is aucthor and ordainer of sinne? and yet to Caluin, and Luther, toLuther lib de l. arb. Calum. l. 1. Inst cap. 3. all Protestantes he seemeth in this an Euangelister! Doe not theese infernall harpies teache no sinne in vilany, in barbaritie, to endamage an apprehending Protestanter, no good worcke of vertue to be puetly good, or good in puritie, no obseruance of the lawe to be possible or nedefull? and whie? but that men loyter, flying from labor in vertuouse endeuors, and lull themselues a sleepe in securitie, where all sinnes abounde, where the wormes of wicked factes breake oute of the liuing bowelles of pampered panches? where is emong them the christall fountaine of profounde speculation? where is any curbing restrainte to withdraw the will from sensuall disportes? wher is any forcible inuitement to liue a vertu onse life, which be the three principall instrumentes of ciuilitie? Suerly that eye, which can not clearly take a veue of theese wantes emong Protestants, liueth in Egypte, and knoweth no darckenes: he nedeth the Chelidonian stoone to restore dec • ied nature, beeing far from any accidentall endoument, or excellency in this respecte: he that perceiueth not theese de • ectes to be occasioned througe the very genius and drifte of Protestancie, well may he be proude, but not for excesse in science, but rather for extremity of follie and ignorance.

Wee are then for the present, to proue to we thinges against the Prostant: first that the whole purpose of his doctrine tendeth to the disgrace of Christ his metitt, empareth such meanes of his bountie, as hathe beene by the same purchased for vs to attaine vnto perfection of life, and diuine beatitude: as it were damming vp the flude of God his mercies through our Sauiour Christ, by which is conuayed to the paradice of his churche the liquor of heauenly dewe, the force of Christian grace, to fertilise our soules, to clense vs from impuritie, to carie vs along in good action contrarie to the maine current and streame of our decaied and depraued natures: so that his steps forewarde of his pretended hope appeare nothing els, but so many proude presumptuouse passages ishuing from his folly, and determining in his oune ruin, his moste miserable and lamentable destruction. Secondly shall wee make a most cleare remonstrance, that his doctrine in the affaire of Christian hope doth so▪
blemish and defile with the excrements of hell, disgorged from the mouthes of olde infamouse heretickes, of Antichrist that man of sinne, the beautie of vertue, that men crediting him, shall haue no iust cause to be inamoured therwith, to make any espetiall regard therof, no • trouble them selues much as atcheue the same: and that contrariewise endeuoring by sundrie Positions to maske and excuse the deformitie of vice, to lessen the greuouse and hatefull harme encurred therby, doth consequently encourage mortall menn to accomplish their f • ll course in all iniquitie, and barbaritie, the doughter of loose disportefull carriage. Lett them glose or the will, guilde as the like, the ordu • e of defiled consciences, whilest they seeme to repose on Christ alone for recouery and recure: lett them flatter them selues in the meane season with the inheritance of a deuised libertie, of a refined Ghospell, and of a spatiouse place to daunce the currant of their recom • o • ts: lett them glorie, that in their garden they gather nothing but roses withoute thornes, the course there aboute the allies and mazes withoute restraincte: the rest and sleepe on the verdure of their late inuented pleasant Phancies: yett this is, and shall bee the vpshott, and I hope Epitaphte read by the world of their doctrine, and endeuors, That men cont • mne vertue, and d • eade no vice.

Contrariewise as our Catholick hope is passing stronge, so is it allso excedinglie pure and vertuouse: the former is caused by this, that we hope throughe deuine grace, the which is most potent and firme: the other procedeth from sych meanes as Christian hope vseth to attaine her ende and purpose. Let man his hope sayeth S. Augustin, so be setled on God, that he Aug Ena • ▪ a in Psalm. 90. nether be allured from him by pleasure, nor broken throughe feare. There be towe principall affections, against which vertue is to striue: that is wanton and vaine loue, and allso drouping dreade. By loue we trespasse against vertue, preferring before it the opposite and forbidden delight: by feare of losse we leaue our station, & performe not that, which is apoinctedArist. in mag. Mor. ca 8. Apoc. 16. by vertue. Wherupon thus concludeth Aristotle: wherfore vertue is employed aboute pleasures, and dolors. Therefore that is a preposterouse hope, yea an inhumane and deformed expectation, which loketh for beatitude without all dependance of vertue and trew ciuilitie: as yf one might through Christ ariue to eternall blisse, and yet permit his loue to yelde to concupiscence, suffer his feare to worcke the omission of that good office, which is prescribed by vertue: and in deede suche a hope as this is, founde in the Protestant, is no thing els, butt the witch Circes her cupp to transforme mē into beastes, and in deede that goble • , which the Babilonian strumpet, daughter to Antichrist, and mothermistresse of all Protestantes, tendreth to all, whose liquor droncke by thē turneth their estates to that
condicion, which is proper to the bratts and slaues of the beast, that man of sinne Antichrist. Our Christian hope then ought to be puisant and resolute; yet pure and honest; and in that respecte more pure and honest, because it is not Philosophicall, but Christian, not humane, but deuine. Consider th • n, I beseeche the G • ntle Reader, first, what reliance hath the Catholick hope on vertue, whose ancher taketh holde on the goodnes of allmighty God, and allso vpon the goodnes of life & action, allthough in a diuerse qualitie: not presuming with an vncleane repose, as sinfull touche, to lay holde on puritie it selfe. On the other side seriouslie way with thy selfe, how a Protestant by eficacie of his pretended hope is not onely defiled, but likewise emboldened by sacrilegiouse conceipt, as yf from heauen he were assured that his hope diuorced from vertue were sufficiently auaileable to a • cheue his finall ende of happines. wherupon must thou nedest conclude, that faithe to be accepted of the, which bringeth forth a vertuouse Hope: and such auouched faith to be reiected, which boldly lanceth in to the debth of all iniquitie: which acertaineth men of their saluation, when suarming with vices they looke in presumptiō for that croune, which is ende & period of all mans endeauors.

In what pittifull plight must then be plunged that common wealth, in which, with Machiauilian pollicie concurreth and accordeth Protestantish Theologie? The Machiauilian will aduertise the Prince, that his assurance of estate dependeth on the sinnes and basenes of his subiectes, as vpon their disagrementes, vpon their voluptuouse riott and effeminacie, vpon their si • plicitie, slauerie and ignorance: then the Protestantish minister will preach▪ bothe to Prince, and subiecte, that no wickednes is to be • mputed • nto a beleuer, that the law of God and nature is impossible, that vertue is nether commendable, nor priseable, that ciuill l • wes oblige not the conscience, that sinnes by abolishment are neuer assoiled, that the Rule of faith is eache mans priuate spiritt enterpreting the worde, that allmost no heresie is damnable: That the splendor and substance of outeward Relligion is superstition or idolatry: & so when all are possessed with theese principles of courte, and Pulpit, the hearers and crediters as they will be lauish for vice, and disdainefull towards verue and heauen, so finallie their manners, besides offence against God, & trespasse against Nature, besides mi • prisall of the crosse of Christ, will be resolued into barbarisme: for as nothing is truly ciuill but learning, and vertue, so nothing balefully barbarouse but ignorance, and iniqui • ie. Alas, what la • dable maiestry is it in waye of pollicie, to induce the rude popularitie into a relligion, & to confirme them in the same, which is gratefull to sense, proportionable to the inclination of flesh & bloode
in their distempe • atures. The Turchishe discipline of gouernemēt dependeth principally vpon these thre apoinct • ments: first that the vnderstanding bee not troubled with any difficultie in matter of faith: then that sensualitie be gratified by free acce • se, with all indemnitie, of carnall pleasures: lastely, that presentement of horrible penalties • nforce bodies & soules into slauerie and vtter dastardie: all which serue as instrumentes to retaine in office and dutie that base generation. Contrariewise a thing prayesable is it, and worthy a ciuill gouernour so to dispose the haertes of subiectes, that willingly they submitt their mindes to obiectes of beleefe, which exceede naturall reach, and as it were trauerse the course therof: then to encline their affections to such obseruances, as be austere, ircksome, and afflicti • e to concupiscence: finallie to make vertue so powerable with them, that terror do not so much moue them to good abearance, as a cordiall loue of vertue, and espe • ially, an inflamed charitie towardes God and man. This, This was the course of pollicie, which our auncient and renoumed fore fathers haue held, so gloriouse vnto them, & auailelable to vs, enioying now the fruictes of their ra • e wisdome & constitutions.
